description:
A game that brings to life how data flows through Internet networks. Put simply, over the course of the game, from two to five participants seek to avoid busy city centres and routes blocked by diggers to deliver data blocks from one city Internet Exchange to another.

Data, however, scores differently and is also subject to cyber attacks from other nasty trouble-making players. But at the end of the day, the first player to fifteen points can celebrate a well-earned victory.

How to Play:
There are a variable number of rounds, with each player, during their individual turn, able to perform any two of the following actions:

Bring a data block into play 
Move a data block along a route
Carry out a cyber-attack

The core of the game are the Location tokens.
Each location token bears the name of a location on the board where there is an Internet Exchange. 
From time to time, players either leave these locations or have to reach them to deliver their data blocks and gain the points they need to win the game. 
Players need to find a container where they can put the tokens, shake them well, and then pick them out one by one as the game progresses.
Data are represented by wooden cubes; they move along the routes on the playing board towards the locations that host Internet Exchanges.

In addition, players can place a digger (only one) on any route after finishing their turn and before the turn passes to the next player. Placing a digger on a route blocks the route.

-description from designer

Creativity Wins!: Outrageous is a hot new party game, where players use their creativity to come up with witty, unique, & hilarious answers to modern-day prompts. Laugh all night long with witty answer prompts. Ex: "I'd hide if ___ showed up at my door." "They should sell ____ in vending machines."
How to Play: Designated judge picks a card & reads aloud. Players write their answers on a sheet & place into box. Answers are read by judge & points are awarded based on best answers. Most points wins!

Adaptable: Outrageous is great for any groups, parties, or birthdays. Depending on participants, games can be family friendly, wild, or "adults only". Inspiration play make the perfect card games for families on game night. Everyone can be OUTRAGEOUS!

Fun for the Family: Recommended for 4-8 players, 13 Years and up. More players can play with additional pencils. You will have the best games with your friends and family.
Game Play: Takes just 5 mins to learn. Each game lasts approximately 30 mins. Play a short round or all night long!

COMES WITH: 220 prompt cards, answer pad, 8 pencils, and instruction booklet

Deck the halls and roll the dice in this holiday game of chance and strategy! In Decorations, you will use your dice rolls to carefully place ornaments and lights on your Christmas tree, aiming for the perfect combination to earn the most points. With a mix of luck and skill, can you create the most dazzling tree?

Designed for one player and taking just 15 minutes, Decorations is perfect for kids aged 8 and up. So grab your dice and get ready to trim the tree in this merry and exciting game!

In Galle Fort, the players are attempting to build a lighthouse in the port of Galle, an important trading post in Sri Lanka.

During the game, players will either take resources from a central pool or trade them for other resources.  One of the key actions is turning in tea to invite another player to a tea party, where you will demand all of one of their types of resources unless they pay one of the available bribes.

The first player to acquire three building materials, thereby erecting the lighthouse, wins.

Alliance: Supergra Strategiczna is a "Strategy and Diplomacy" multi-player board wargame that simulates a theoretical War in Europe in the '30s.
Seven Nations: Britain, France, Italy, Germany, Romania, Poland, and Turkey are trying to eliminate the competitors.
When four Nations are defeated (no more cities controlled) the remaining three nations share the victory.
Diplomacy is required to gain an advantage.

Gameplay - key rules:

     All Players write down their commands on the paper, then all moves take place at the same time.
     There are two types of orders: attack (move), or defend.
     Attack or defend can be declared for the current territory or for the territory next to it.
     Each unit can move to the territory that shares the border with the current one.
     To conquer a hostile space - attacker power (number of units) needs to be higher than defender power.
     Each year has two phases (Spring and autumn campaigns)
     When the Year ends - units calculation takes place - for each conquered terrain - the player may build a new unit.
     Special units = cost of 3 regular units.


Win Condition:
Each Nation starts with three cities, and when all cities are lost - that Nation is eliminated. When 4 Nations are eliminated - the game ends and the remaining 3 Nations share the victory.

Note: While this game may seem similar to the Alliace from Columbia Games, it has different mechanics, counties, and background.

In Robot Roll & Write, each player builds their own robot over the course of twelve turns, adding components to the shell of the body, then connecting them with circuits in order to score points.

At the start of every third turn, lay out five cards on the display in the dice slots 1-5. Each card shows a component or two different circuits; some cards also have a die depicted on them. One card at random has a special token on it. On a turn, each player rolls two six-sided dice, then uses the results of the dice to choose one or two cards and add the components or circuitry to their robot shell. A result of 6 always lets you choose any card, but if a card has a second die depicted on it then you need both that die result and a 6 (or the designated die slot 1-5).

Offensive le Jeu is a simple and effective educational tool to explain military operations up to the brigade level. It is particularly interesting for officer or student training. Generic in nature, it allows a wide range of player-generated scenarios, can be played on a 1:50'000 military map and can be easily house-ruled.

Each side starts with a set of forces and special units, as well as a hand of event and asset cards. The scale of the units' movement on the square grid is realistic, as well as their spotting range and firepower. The games teaches combined arms on the higher tactical level, while allowing for a skillful combination of obstacles, mines, demonstrations and paramilitary groups - the game conveys the idea of a hybrid engagement.

The use of blocks and the combination with event & asset cards allows for good bluffing strategies. Combat is very simple but introduces unit-specific terrain modifiers which work really well together. A lot of additional "chrome" is left out, but the system works and it is simple enough to be extended with logistical rules, command & control, asymmetric forces, or new characteristics for units.

Victory can either be achieved by the destruction of enemy units or after agreeing to a specific scenario victory condition.

—user summary

As you may have understood, Offensive the game is not a game like the others! It was developed for instruction and then adapted for all audiences! So it has kept some characteristics that make the difference:


      The possibility to play on all Swiss topographic maps at 1:50'000 scale.
      Rules that adapt to the level of the players to accompany you on the path of knowledge and tactical understanding.
      Simple rules so that you can get the hang of it quickly! 


Offensive the game is a board game that includes:

      A basic game board;
      66 units to command;
      Offensive cards to influence the battle;
      2 dice to play the confrontations;
      2 types of rules according to your level of play (Novice or expert) which are downloadable on the page of the Internet site.


—description from the publisher (Translated)

Vous l'aurez sans doute compris, Offensive le jeu n'est pas un jeu comme les autres! Il a été développé pour l'instruction est adapté ensuite pour tous les publics! Alors il a gardé certaines caractéristiques qui font la différence:

â€‹*  La possibilité de jouer sur toutes les cartes topographiques suisses à l'échelle 1:50'000.

      Des règles qui s'adaptent au niveau des joueurs pour vous accompagner sur le chemin de la connaissance et de la compréhension tactique.
      Des règles simples afin de pouvoir le prendre en main rapidement! 


Offensive le jeu est donc un jeu de société qui comprend:

      Un plateau de jeu de base;
      66 unités à commander;
      Des cartes Offensive pour influencer la bataille;
      2 dés pour jouer les affrontements;
      2 types de règles suivant votre niveau de jeu (Novice ou expert) qui sont téléchargeables sur la page du site internet.


—description from the publisher (French)

Each player is the captain of a fleet of pirate ships, and their goal is to sink all of the opponents’ ships – shooting cannonades, of course – and remain the only pirate still afloat. During your turn you can add ships to your fleet or try sinking those of your friends by shooting cannonballs at them. Simple? Yes! The game is explained in 30 seconds but finding and developing a strategy to have the upper hand might not be so easy!

—description from the designer

Dicevania: Quintet or Rolls is a double-faced print at home roll & write game, loosely inspired by a famous videogame. Roll your dice, conquer the map, and save the Countess girl!

SIDE A
Use 5d6 trying to score the needed combination in order to clear a room, then move to the nex one. Freely explore the castle, finding and managing your items to modify the rolls, recover HP and score points. Fill the rewards bars with scored points to get more items. Will you explore the whole map?

SIDE B
Roll 5d6 to determine which tetraminoes you'll have to put in the map. Try to cover it completely.

-description from designer

Your Mission? Don’t Go Boom! Get the lowest score in 3 rounds by totaling up the numbers on each player's minefield cards. Watch out for Big Bad Bomb cards, they’re worth 15 points each. Explosively fun card games by Inspiration Play. Inspired by the parlor card game, Golf.

Have a BLAST - Other kids games on the market move slowly and can’t keep attention. The Don’t Go Boom card games for kids keep you and your kids guessing down to the last card. Approx. 25 mins. (2 - 6 players)

Easy To Learn & Play Anywhere - Don’t Go Boom is easy to learn and is perfect for kids ages 7 and up. Action cards help players strategize the best moves and create a fun, engaging vacation, travel, car, recess, or classroom card game your family will love!

Explosive & Calculated Fun - Family card games are where it's at! Improve your kids counting and math skills while having fun and ditching virtual play. Our travel games for kids help teach your child social skills, math, and the art of kicking some serious butt.

Contains 104 cards & instructions.

How to Win? Your mission is to RUIN any given topic with our hilarious adult game. Pull a topic card and ruin the topic in 4 words or less! Convince the judge why you should win the round. The player with the most points WINS.

Comes with 255 topic cards, 8 whiteboards, and 10 markers.

CATNIP Auction House is where the world’s elite cats go to get the best items for their personal collections!

Overview: CATNIP Auction House is a bidding game for 3-8 players. Each player represents a cat that will spend its precious catnip to bid on various items until the inventory is gone.

Game Objective: Have the most Victory Points at the end of the game to win! There are 4 steps to each round:

Step 1: Reveal the item up for auction.
The Auctioneer flips over the top card of the deck to reveal the item that is up for auction this round.

Step 2: Activate Action Item Cards. 
Any player that has a card labelled “instant” can activate its ability by flipping it over. Instant abilities are a one-time use. Any VP labelled on the card counts toward end game scoring regardless of whether the card is active or not.

Step 3: Bid on items.
Starting to the left of the auctioneer, in a clock-wise order, players either bid on the item or they PAWS (pass). If they BID, they place one Catnip Token in the centre of the table.
If that player chooses to PAWS, they place their PAW Token in front of their screen and take all Catnip Tokens from in the centre of the table. They may no longer bid on this item.

Once a player PAWS’ and they are the only player that still hasn't PAWSed, that player will win the item. The last player to PAWS will get the number of mice shown in the bottom right corner of that item card.

Step 4: A new Auctioneer
After the auction item is claimed, the winner of the auction becomes the Auctioneer for the next round and receives the Auctioneer Marker.

-description from publisher
Repeat steps 1 to 4 until all Auction Items are won.

For over 300 million years, trees have traded nutrients with fungi in a vast underground network. Scientists continue to make new discoveries about this hidden world.

In Undergrove, you are a towering evergreen with an ancient symbiotic connection to the fungi in your forest. As new mushrooms appear, your options expand for converting nutrients and helping your seedlings. Using cube conversion, tile placement, area control, and a tiny bit of engine building, you’ll need to claim the most advantageous locations and optimize your actions to leave the best legacy in the forest.  The player with the  greatest number of successful seedlings, wins!

â— Build a shared forest containing mushrooms with diverse abilities.
â— Trade with the mushrooms to get resources based on the partnerships you’ve made.
â— Place your seedings in the most advantageous positions to score the most points.

Inspired by real mycorrhizal trading networks. Shape the destiny of your forest with every decision!

-description from publisher

You are a girl who is very busy preparing for a date that was suddenly decided. You want to be cute and fashionable, but you don't have any of those items! Borrow a lot of fashionable items from other people and aim to go on wonderful dates with as many boys as possible.

In ãƒžãƒƒãƒãƒ³ã‚°ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ (Matching 4U), players will be dealt 8 cards each. They will draft their hand, 2 cards at a time, until they have 8 cards again. Players will then play tricks and determine the strength of their card from highest to lowest.

Starting with the highest strength, players will acquire one of the played cards and leave it face up in front of themselves for scoring at the end of the round. All cards have various set collection bonuses associated with them. You want the most diamonds, you want pairs of shoes, perfume will make your clothes score more, etc.

The player with the most points after 3 rounds is the winner!

Deep Dive is a press-your-luck set-collection game in which you use your waddle of penguins to dive deep into the ocean to amass the most bountiful collection of food!

Turns are simple: Flip over an ocean tile, and see what you reveal. You can take what you reveal in the shallows or dive deeper, hoping for a larger catch — but the deeper you go, the more plentiful the predators become. As you surface with food, you build sets of three colors. Target the colors you need to complete sets and score the maximum number of points.

When one of the depths of the ocean has been fully explored, the game ends and the penguin waddle with the best sets of food wins!

—description from publisher

Mediterranean sea, southwest coast of Sicily island. It was the early morning of 10 July 1943 when the first landing craft dropped their ramps at Gela and the first units of US Rangers set their boots on Italian soil. Together with the British and Canadian units that had landed further east, the Western Allies launched an unprecedented landing operation to push open the gate to Fortress Europe. The night before, on 9 July, American and British airborne troops had already dropped into enemy territory behind the planned beach landing zones to occupy important positions. This was to prevent or delay timely counterattacks by Italian and German troops on the day of the landing. This operation, called Husky, was the beginning of the end of the Italian army as an ally of the German Wehrmacht. It was the additional front, long demanded by Stalin, and thus brought the necessary relief of the Eastern Front.

Assault Sicily 43 is the second volume in a planned series of tactical level wargames in which players lead historical units into battle during the landing and airborne operations around Gela Beachhead in July 1943. Americans, Italians and Germans fight bitterly for the backdoor Sicily as a launchpad for the invasion of the continent.

Game Scale: Squad and team level infantry units, individual vehicles and artillery
Turn time: 5-20 minutes
Game time: 1 hour – 3+ hours, scenario dependent
Complexity: 4 -6 out of 10 (medium)
Optional rules that ease the entry into the game system
Replay value: 10 out of 10
This game can be combined with the Eastern Front module: Assault Red Horizon 41

Who doesn’t love a fun journey? You’re off to adventure on a tropical island! Sunshine, surf and… 3 new cases? Detectives, team up! Meet the residents and tourists on an amazing beach and help the animals figure out what happened!

Once upon an Island is a co-operative adventure for young detectives. Your goal is to piece the full picture, just like a jigsaw puzzle, and re-create the events. Find out what actually happened in this stand-alone game from the Detecteam Kids range!

The title translates to "The mysterious House".

Three valuable objects are hidden inside a mysterious house. In order to find them, the players have to solve riddles on each card. Their faithful companion Snuffles is always by their side. But the players can only reveal the house's secrets and solve all the riddles with the help of an UV lamp.

Three exciting chapters provide 20 minutes of fun playing time each. To help solve the riddles, various clue cards can be used for help. Kids can set up the house and explore it in 3D.

Kids who enjoy adventures and riddles will have a great time exploring the 3D house and all its secrets.

Title translates to "From Err to Z"

A crazy and fun explaining and guessing game for everyone. The players try to explain as many words as possible to the other team which has to guess the correct term. The clue: The wanted term can only be explained with the displayed letter. If, for example, one player draws a card with the letter "S" on it, his/her teammates can only use this letter to explain the wanted word until the next letter card is drawn. Assuming the wanted word is "Fish", the players could give hints like "Swims! Scales!" A stop watch with 90 seconds adds extra suspense.

"Angriff auf die Schneefestung" (German for "Assault on the Snow Fort") is an asymmetric microgame for 2 players in postcard format.

The game is played on a grid of 5x5 spaces. Both players secretly choose their actions and then reveal and perform them simultaneously.

One player attacks the snow fort and can only move forward, either straight or diagonally. They win the game by reaching the row right in front of the fort without being caught.

The other player defends the fort and can only move left or right or stay in place. The defender always throws a snowball at the end of their turn. If the attacker is located in the same column as the defender, they get hit and have to retreat 2 spaces. The defender wins by pushing the attacker out of the grid or by ending their action on the same space as the attacker.

-description from designer

A hand-building game where players try to get as close to 10 or -10 as possible without going beyond. However, if any player reaches exactly either score, someone else can swipe the victory with a score of exactly 0.

On your turn, you can either play a card and draw a card to improve your hand, or you may call, letting everyone else know that the pressure is on them to finish up. The game can be finished in less than 5 minutes, making it great on the go, and as a warm-up on game night.

Several variations are mentioned in the rules to let you customize the game to your need.

Roll the character die and whoever rolls higher gets to "pop" the bubbles on the opposing pop it.  If both players roll the same result then the dice are up for grabs and whoever grabs them first gets to pop the sum of the dice.  The player who completely pops the opposing character is the winner.

ãƒ‘ãƒ³ãƒ”ãƒ³ãƒãƒ³ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ  (Pang Ping Pong Game) is a speed card game from Japan. Similar to Uno, players must play their cards to the discard pile as quickly as possible. But the cards must be played in order: Pang>Ping>Pong>pang and so on. Players play as quickly as they can in no turn order, but a player cannot play twice to pile; another player must play a card before they can play again. The first player to shed their hand wins the round, and winning three rounds wins the game.

There are also special cards such as double cards like PangPing which counts as player two in a row, and Skip, which lets you skip a card in order: Pang>Skip>Pong.
Match-play golf simulation game, playing item, prank and caddie cards, rolling club dice to solve the direction.

A print-and-play game of daring adventurers in dangerous dungeons.

You play as a brave adventurer in a fantasy world of magic and monsters.

You explore a map, fighting enemies as you go, searching for treasure in every corner.

After a limited number of rounds, each player that has defeated the dangerous boss enemy compares their collected loot. The player with the most gold is the winner!

Each hero has their own advantages and special abilities. Each map presents a different set of challenges. By playing different combinations of heroes and maps, the game provides a variety of experiences and stays fresh through many plays.

—description from the publisher

Nelly and her friends hunt a vampire in the mountains. To get there, they need to use Calm, Learning and Cunning!

Nelly Rapp's Vampire Hunt is a game for 2-4 players that trains deduction skills and logic.

The player who can best balance planning and risk-taking will catch the vampire!

The players start at a school and have to pass through several tiles using command cards. The first person reaching the end tile defeats the vampire.

Alien Siege allows you to take part in the Marines’ first encounter with the Aliens, in the chamber under the reactor. It is based in Aliens, the 1986 science fiction/horror film.

The game may be played by one or more people. The player (or players) run the squad of 9 Marines; the Aliens pretty much run themselves, following an easy set of rules.

The game ends when all the Marines have left the room through the doorway at the north end of the Map, or have been dragged off by the Aliens.

This game is a simplified form of the standard Leading Edge system. Used, for example, in Phoenix Command.

The authorship of the game is not indicated, only the © of Leading Edge Games is mentioned, but quite possibly the authors are Barry Nakazono and David McKenzie, designers also of Phoenix Command and Aliens.

Was included in Gateways Magazine #10.

General info on Krimi Total:

Murder mystery game in which players act out their role and try to solve the mystery.

Info on this particular case (in German):

Es ist ein wunderschöner Tag. In einer kleinen Stadt, irgendwo in der Nähe von Moskau, gibt heute Viktor Lasarew, Russlands mächtigster Diamantenbaron, die Hand seiner Tochter dem ätherisch schönen Sohn seines indischen Geschäftspartners.

Der Festsaal auf dem Anwesen der Lasarews erstrahlt in all seiner Pracht. Prunkvolle Kronleuchter, goldbesetztes Geschirr und mit Diamantsplittern versehene Tischdekoration warten auf das Eintreffen der Hochzeitsgäste. Alles ist für die Hochzeit des Jahres vorbereitet.

Doch der Bräutigam wird seine bezaubernde Braut nicht mehr in ihrem Hochzeitskleid sehen! Soeben wurde sein Leichnam gefunden ...

55 Days at Peking is a low to moderate complexity tactical wargame on the Chinese siege of the Legations at Peking in 1900. The game takes about 90 minutes to play. One player commands the Chinese forces and the other player commands the various Allied forces defending the Legations.
Action and Event Cards vary the game play.

The British 50th Infantry Division, landing to the west of the 3rd Canadian Infantry Division, made good gains on D-Day and looked like it would be able to advance on Bayeux on the 7th without problem.  After consolidating for the night the British moved out smartly in the morning to the south along the road toward Bayeux.  For the 2 days they would make some headway, and then be stopped cold for weeks by Panzer Lehr, possibly the best Panzer Division in the German Army.  The fight between these 2 divisions would become legendary during the campaign and filled with vicious combat.

—description from the designer

Christmas Would You Prefer? is a conversation game, best played in a group, but it can also be played between two individuals.

Everyone takes a turn at answering a question.  They choose by picking a card at random.  Once they have given their answer out loud, the rest of the group then takes a poll about the same question, and if the player's answer matches that of the majority, the player earns a point.  Players choose how many rounds of questions there will be.

The game concludes when each player has answered a question in each round.  The person with the most points wins.

The factory of the world of dreams is on the brink of destruction! The Evil Cogs have sabotaged all the machines, and it is only a matter of minutes before everything implodes. At the head of a robot squad, will you manage to repair the factory before all the failsafes have collapsed?

Cyberion is a game of hand-management, and you must use your robot cards wisely, either to repair the machine cards or to trigger powerful effects. The machines get harder to repair throughout the game, but you'll also have opportunities to increase the magnitude of the effects your robot can trigger.

—description from the designer

The Monopoly Discover board game offers fun teaching tools for families. It features a double-sided gameboard with 2 levels of play, so you can decide which level is right for the family! One side focuses on counting and matching, recommended for kids ages 4-5. Flip the board over for more advanced play, focusing on reading and simple math, recommended for kids ages 6 and up. Gameplay in each level uses its own set of Monopoly money and cards, as well as rules. Inspired by Monopoly classic gameplay -- after all, every billionaire starts somewhere! The game is a great choice for a family game night, and makes a fun gift for kids ages 4 and up. The Hasbro, Hasbro Gaming, Parker Brothers, and Monopoly names and logos, the distinctive design of the gameboard, the four corner squares, the Mr. Monopoly name and character, as well as each of the distinctive elements of the board and playing pieces are trademarks of Hasbro for its property trading game and game equipment.


     LEARN, EARN, AND GROW: It's a game that grows with kids! The Monopoly Discover board game presents playful teaching tools for families
     2 LEVELS OF PLAY: The 2-sided gameboard offers 2 levels of play: One side focuses on counting and matching for little kids. Flip the board over for a focus on reading and simple math for big kids
     ADORABLE MONOPOLY TOKENS: Kids will love using the Monopoly tokens: Penguin, Car, Ducky, Scottie, Hazel, and Rex
     2 SETS OF MONEY AND CARDS: Each level includes its own set of Monopoly money and cards, appropriate for that level
     SIMPLIFIED MONOPOLY GAMEPLAY: From the makers of Monopoly Junior, this board game is designed to be fast, fun, and an exciting game for kids ages 4 and up


—description from the publisher

The year is 1954. The Algerian people are rising up against French colonizers who have oppressed them for over a century. But this is no regular war - victory will not be achieved on the battlefield, but by winning the hearts and minds of everyday Algerians.

Insurgent: Algeria is a simple, asymmetric card game for 1 to 2 players which recreates the Algerian War for independence on your tabletop. Players take the role of the French government and the Algerian resistance [the FLN], which have separate faction decks with unique abilities.

The game can be won in two ways - attrition and domination. An attrition victory involves collecting the most public support, represented by the icons on the top of the cards, in two of three fronts - military, political and diplomatic. A domination victory occurs when a player overwhelms their opponent in any one front. Players must balance these competing objectives strategically in order to win the game.

The solo game pits the Algerian player against a French AI, which is simple to implement but provides a difficult challenge since the AI plays cards faster than the two-player game allows.

-description from designer

The Battle of Shiloh, or Pittsburg Landing, April 6-7, 1862.
The 9th title in the Last Full Measure series.
250 yards per hex on a 19 x 24 inch map.  5/8 inch counters and 1/2 inch markers.  Units are regiments and batteries.

Johnston's Confederate Army of the Mississippi attacks Grant's Army of the Tennessee encamped just inshore of Pittsburg Landing on the Tennessee River with the goal of destroying it before Buell's Army of the Ohio can arrive.

Players receive victory points for eliminating enemy strength points and taking certain geographic objectives; the player with the most points at the conclusion of a scenario wins.

—description from designer

Var i Världen? ("Where in the World?") tests your knowledge of our world. You may know that the Serengeti is a famous national park, but can you point it out on the map too? In Var i Världen? all players answer (or guess) the same questions on topics such as: history, food, culture, sports, music, architecture, literature, nature, geography, art and language.

After a question is read, each player takes turns placing a cube on the board (which is a world map divided into squares) where they think is the correct place for what is being asked. An example of a question might be "This is the southernmost capital city in the world".

Several players can place in the same square and everyone who has placed in the correct square gets a point. First player to collect 10 points wins. Each player also has special cubes marked with +1 or +2 and which allow you to expand the area for correct answers. These can only be used once and then removed from play. Some questions can also give extra points if you also mark the correct year on a timeline.

—user summary

16 Candies is a fast-paced and sweet family game for 3-4 players. In each round, players draw and discard cards featuring different types of candy, trying to form the best hand they can with their 3 cards.

When a player thinks they have the best hand, they can shout "I GOT CANDY!" Opposing players will have 1 final turn to optimize their hand before the round ends, at which point all players will reveal their hands. The player with the worst hand must remove a penalty amount of candy from their starting supply of 16 cardboard candies (or real candy, if you choose to play with it).

The game ends when only one player has candy left in their supply, and that player is the winner. With quick turns and a fun theme, 16 Candies is a tasty treat for game nights with family and friends.

-description from designer

Caesar - is a brand new dice game by Reiner Knizia  set in Ancient Rome. Get the support of the other Senators and the coins you need to put you at the top. But be wary of revolts - they can ruin your support - or give you the final edge to overthrow the game and become Caesar in the end.

The competitive game for 2- 6 players. The game ends after 5 rounds. Each player rolls the unidice during their turn. The top and sides of the digital die turn into their own D6 which means you roll a total of 5 dice in one unidice. The dice results range from numbers to senators and revolt. During their turn, a player can reroll and lock and unlock die faces up to 3 times. Since final dice results can give a senator an advantage, they can choose to aim for a certain dice result to overthrow the other players.

Caesar is a brand new turn-based game you can play with the unidice - a gaming console in the shape of a die. A player can roll/reroll 3 times until the final result is confirmed. The game proceeds automatically to the next player's turn. Automating the roles with the app and unidice makes reading rules becomes almost redundant as you learn the game on the fly.

—description from the designer

In Egg Rolling! players race with their birds to finish first on top of the track which leads upword to the top of the slide.

During a turn a player roll a dice and as a consequence moves their bird pawn 1/2/3 spaces upwords or alternatively roll the egg from the top of the slide in hope to knock their opponents pawns. Knocked pawn starts from the bottom (beginning of the track).

The first player on top wins.

Komma Lika (Come Equally)

Every time you do something for the shared household – the dishes, replace a broken light bulb, take the car to the auto shop, etc. – you get points. The points consist of triangular shaped magnets of different sizes. Each member of the household gets his/her own color, and together the different colored magnets form a nice pattern. When the game period is finished, the colors should ideally be balanced and equally distributed. Everybody wins by getting equal.

It is up to you to decide how long you want the game period to be. A week or two, until you run out of magnets, or until you together have formed one of the figures shown on the cards that come with the game.

Try playing a first round while leading your lives as usual, collecting points according to the rules. Evaluate the results. Are the colors balanced? Play again – this time, try to get as equal as possible.

Who wins? It’s not about winning – it’s about getting equal.

The Inertia Corporation is coming, after your crew discovered something about them you shouldn’t have. Now you must survive the onslaught surrounding you.

Gun It is a timed cooperative game in which players are packed together in a car in the middle of a thriller.

Over a series of rounds, the crew must collaborate to shoot their way through a hostile array of cars, trucks, motorcycles, and more. Each round, players will have limited time to exchange cards determining who shoots and drives where, when, and with which equipment. Once time runs out, the action begins! But plan wisely, as vehicles explode, often causing collateral damage and chains of vehicle destruction that come back to blow up in your face.
Survive long enough to achieve your current scenario in style!

Each scenario has a victory condition with multiple levels of success. Each may require you to earn XP, create pileups, or eliminate rivals. If the crew ends in a wreck or you fail to complete the minimum victory condition, the game ends in failure!

—description from the designer

A solitaire dice & card game. Fly bombing missions as the crew of a B17 flying fortress in World War 2.

Can your crew survive long enough to complete their bombing mission and be back in time for supper?! Fight and fend of enemy fighters and get through enemy flak to reach your bombing targets in a pivotal role in World War 2 to aid Allied war effort.

—description from the designer

Official link to game
https://thekealf.itch.io/b17-bomber-defense-a-solitaire-dice-cardgame

Tiny Ninjas: Tournament is a collection of challenging dexterity mini games for 1-4 players.
Played right inside of the Game Box, Tiny Ninjas: Tournament is immensely portable and takes up very little space. 
An entire tournament system the size of a book. Take it with you anywhere you go and play on virtually any surface. 
Rules and scoring for each game are incredibly simple and can be learned in seconds. 
To master these games however will take a keen eye and a steady hand. 
Gameplay is lightning-fast and very addicting.
Score more points and reach new heights - become the Ninja Champion!

You play as a youngster in the spring of 1927. The ice is breaking up in the fjärds of central Stockholm. The object of the game is to dare your friends to stay the longest on the ice sheets that are continuously breaking. 
Place your meeples on a paper and tear out the biggest possible piece without toppling any meeples. Then play the pieces you have collected to win.

—description from the designer

Do you think the pig will take first place?

Some animals are faster than other, but in this game you decide, so everything is possible. At the same time you have to bet on which animals you think will win, and the sooner you bet the bigger the reward.

First and foremost it has to be fun to play, but at the same time give you a simple understanding of probability. In addition there is strategy, bluff and co-operation - so everybody has a chance of winning.

The game is Danish designe and produced in environmentally friendly materials, amongst some incredible good people from the Copenhagen Northwest neighbourhood.

Published in 100 copied in December 2022

Player take turns to roll three dice, choose to re-roll 1-3 of those dice once. Move animals in the lanes rolled. Buy betting cards and chance cards.

Once three animals are in the goal, players will receive income based on the number of betting- and chance-cards that corresponds with the winning (1st trough 3rd) animals.

—description from the publisher (translated)

To begin, players must choose 3 champions to build a deck around them and their classes.

Decks are built of cards representing magical artifacts, weapons and armor, legends of the world, allied creatures, minions, realms, and campaigns. If your strategy is well-planned, these cards will work synergistically and lead you to victory.

Combat is essential to achieve victory. Your champions, allies, and minions will fight under your command against your opponent’s forces. Every time you attack, all unblocked damage points will become victory points.

Each turn has a structure, based in phases. During each phase, you can do certain actions, including playing cards. However, playing them has a cost: you must use experience points. These points are earned every turn from your champions, destroying opposing allies and minions, or completing campaign objectives.

The player who defeats the three opposing champions, or the first to collect 20 victory points, wins the game. A player with no more cards to draw loses the game.â€‹â€‹

—description from the designer

The game consist of one cheese piece and 12 mice figures.

There are two variants of the rules:

     Players stack the mice on top of the cheese. The first player that makes the tower collapse loses. All other players win.
     Players stack the mice on the table. When a player makes any mice fall, they take all the fallen mice. The first player to place their last mouse wins.

The legendary pirate 'Golden Hook' has disappeared! Countless treasures he left behind are buried in this island and that island!
4 pirate captains fighting for treasure island! Whose pirate crew will become a legend?

In Scribble Pirates, each player becomes a pirate boss, protects your own pirate ship, destroys the opponent's pirate ship, captures the treasure island, and develops your base to earn points. The game ends and the player with the most points wins.

—description from the designer

Welcome to the future! Welcome to what counts as parole in today's prison system. So, you want out? You're tired of making money for The System through hard labor? Well, if you want out early, you'll have to make up for lost profits by going through the Robot Maze. An event televised to a paid viewing audience where you have to make it out of a maze while being tracked by Robots!

In this PnP game you have an A4 map of a maze printed out. You start out in the middle of the bottom of the maze and have to move through it to one of the two exits at the top corners in order to win. You can move up to one square each turn.

But in the middle of the maze 4 robots await you and move according to the die result that you throw for each robot each turn. When you come into their line of sight, they will move onto your square and you lose. So be sure to plan your movement carefully!

Do you have what it takes to make it out safely?!?

Horticulture is a casual strategy game. In this game everyone plans and plants their own beautiful garden--complete with garden gnome and meandering path. Score points by accomplishing the plan you have designed, by grouping similar plants together, filling your window box and planting near your garden gnome.

Players take turns picking the plants everyone must add to their garden and everyone simultaneously draws the chosen plants in their garden.

—description from the designer
